photo.description: Limax maximus (or great grey slug, or leopard slug) is one of the largest kinds of keeled air-breathing land slug in the world. This one is crawling on one of the Roman road in the Forum Magnum, in Rome, between the Temple of Antoninus and Faustina and the Arch of Septimius Severus. IMG_4651
photo.tags: italy rome slug limax maximus greatgreyslug limaxmaximus leopardslug forummagnum
photo.title: Limax maximus forum magnum

photo.title: Arch of Septimius Severus (Roman Forum)

photo.description: In the background: The arch of Septimius Severus, a triumphal arch erected in AD 205 to commemorate the Parthian victories of Emperor Septimius Severus and his two sons, Caracalla and Geta, in the two campaigns against the Parthians of 195 and 203.
photo.tags: rome italy ruins forum roman columns arch
photo.title: Roman forum

photo.description: The three columns are what remains of the temple of Castor and Pollux in the roman forum. In the background to the left is the Temple of Vesta. The temple was originally built in gratitude for victory at the battle of Lake Regillus (495 BC). Castor and Pollux (Greek Polydeuces) were the Dioscuri, the "twins" of Gemini, the twin sons of Zeus (Jupiter) and Leda. Their cult came to Rome from Greece via Magna Graecia and the Greek culture of Southern Italy.
photo.tags: rome italy ruins forum roman castor pollux columns temple
photo.title: Temple of Castor and Pollux

photo.description: Torso from a cuirassed statue of Nero. Marble. Neronian period. From the area of the Roman theater (Piazze dei Celestini), Bologna. Bologna, Museo Civico Archeologico. On display at the Curia for the Nero exhibition in Rome.

photo.description: Bust of Luna marble, Herm of Africano marble. Neronian period (54-68 CE). From the sacellum Herculis on the Viale Trastevere, Rome (1889). Rome, Museo Nazionale Romano, Palazzo Massimo alle Terme. On display at the Curia for the Nero exhibition in Rome.

photo.description: Rome, Italy.
photo.title: Forum Romanum

photo.description: A panel of carvings in the Curia Julia. These are the Plutei Traiani, a set of carved stone balustrades built by Trajan. They are on display inside the Curia Julia on the Forum Romanum today, but are not part of the original structure. More about this can be found at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plutei_of_Trajan For more about the Curia Julia (the Roman Senate House) have a look at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curia_Julia
photo.tags: andantetravels curiajulia italy makingoftheromans pluteitraiani rome antiquity ruins lazio
photo.title: Curia Carvings

photo.description: Arch of Septimius Severus on the right and Musei Captionlini in the background.
photo.title: Northwest of Roman Forum

photo.description: The three columns are what remains of the temple of Castor and Pollux in the roman forum. The temple was originally built in gratitude for victory at the battle of Lake Regillus (495 BC). Castor and Pollux (Greek Polydeuces) were the Dioscuri, the "twins" of Gemini, the twin sons of Zeus (Jupiter) and Leda. Their cult came to Rome from Greece via Magna Graecia and the Greek culture of Southern Italy.
photo.tags: rome italy ruins forum roman columns temple castor pollux
photo.title: Temple of Castor and Pollux

photo.description: In the background: The arch of Septimius Severus, a triumphal arch erected in AD 205 to commemorate the Parthian victories of Emperor Septimius Severus and his two sons, Caracalla and Geta, in the two campaigns against the Parthians of 195 and 203.
